posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone. My team is having CAN issues again, and we are wondering how teams approach debugging them, and also, how teams avoid CAN issues set-up wise. Is there something your team does differently, and you haven’t had issues since?

I want to get to the stage where I can easily diagnose issues (and not spend 50 hours staring at wires).

posts.name: Brandon Chan
posts.cooked: So I’m looking at the REV LED Pattern Codes and the closest I can find to the problem is orange/yellow according to REV this means that it means a CAN fault. Now if you are sure its red and definitely not orange then for some reason its showing two different states which is coast mode and reverse mode. Not sure if that was what you were looking for but thats what the colors mean. Now the CAN issue, remember the CAN you can track from PDP to Rio or vice versa. Now the first thing I do is look if the CAN wires are backwards (green to yellow) if not that then look if the CAN wires are connected to each motor controller is backwards like (ex: motor controller (mc1) has a green connected to mc2 then has a yellow connected to mc3 and so on) there could also be a bad wire but highly unlikely and if all else fails I’d rewire lol

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Check the status blink codes of your devices, they can tell you if it is not on the network or if there is a CAN ID collision.

Check the configuration software (Phoenix tuner, Rev hardware client, Alchemist …)   IT can tell you if you have collisions and which devices it can’t see, this should point you towards a connection that may be problematic.

Using a multimeter on resistance mode is a good step.  Break the CAN at some point and  check the resistance towards the termination and towards the RIO.  On both sides you should see 115-125 Ohm resistance.   If you see more you have a break or a high resistance connection in that direction, if you see less you have a short.  You can keep working toward the bad connection.

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked:
Here are some things that work for us:

No connectors when possible and rock solid connectors when needed. We are using the Molex connectors and love the reliability.

Keep wire runs as short as possible. Once someone created a loop to secure excess wires - that really messed our signals.

Detailed plans so we can easily trace the path.

Green to green, yellow to yellow. This is why we like the Molex connectors as our approach prevents plugging in the wrong way

Double checking the CAN id of devices before they go on the robot. Devices with the same id can cause issues. Based on your description this would be the first thing I check.

Wire gauge, if your wires are too small (ie. 24awg) it is much harder to strip and crimp the wires. We found 20awg to be a great option.

Look at how you prep the wires to install into the roborio and pdh. Do you use ferrules or tin them? How do you avoid strands sticking out?

When stripping wires take time to measure them to ensure they meet the requirements for the connector you are using. Take time to watch and read the documentation from the manufacturer.

CAN wiring is the nerve network for your robot, methodical, precision are the words to live by!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
GronkBaby:

As for our own issue, when we plug a certain Spark Max in, everything starts flickering red and yellow (alternating, so sometimes red, sometimes yellow), but when it’s unplugged, everything turns yellow and works again. Would this be a tell-tale sign for something?

By “everything turns yellow”, are you saying that the status LED on each SparkMAX on your robot becomes solid yellow? Solid yellow is the status code for a valid idle signal for a brushed motor in coast mode.  Are you running all brushed motors (e.g. CIM , 775pro, BAG) with your SparkMAXes?  Have you set them all to coast mode?  If you are running NEOs, NEO550s, or Vortexes, you should expect to see cyan (light blue) on those SparkMAXes at idle if they are in brake mode (most common) or magenta (pinkish purple) if they are idle in coast mode (less common).

I’m assuming that you are using all V2 CAN cables with the external wire loop at the white connector for your SparkMAXes if you can unplug a CAN cable from a SparkMAX and the rest of the CAN bus stays up and functional.  Are those the cables you are using?  If not, I’m wondering what kind of CAN bus topology you might have.  Are you running a straight daisy chain from the roboRio to each CAN device sequentially and then ending at the PDH / PDP ?

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
We ended up figuring it out Like maybe all CAN issues, it was something very stupid - an encoder connection had gotten loose and gotten disconnected and was short-circuiting.

I appreciate the help though!

posts.name: Hassan Naqvi
posts.cooked:
There’s a lot of things that can go wrong with CAN tbh but usually I’ll start with double checking that CAN is wired and terminated in both ends To do that I’ll get a multimeter and test the resistance between the low and high sides and double check that the resistance is 60 ohms. You should also check for continuity

between the high and low side to see if there’s any shorts

between the beginning of the yellow wire to the end to see if there’s a break

same for green side

With that you can test your connections and see whether there’s a break or a short in the chain. Then I usually check all the connections (either WAGO, locking Molex, or soldered connections) My team (5032) stopped using wagos and now we just primarily solder all our connections, I’ve had a lot of problems with wagos and don’t like them for signal connections overall. If that doesn’t work then just isolate each component one by one and see what component/connection is the issue. It takes a while but it’s worth it if it means you can make your wiring better. Some other tips I have are

keep can wires twisted to reduce interference

keep can separate from power, usually I try putting our power wires on a bottom layer, and then put can and other signal wires above.

think about your CAN topology and your wiring scheme/cable management well ahead of time, good electrical takes a lot of planning and messing around to see what works for you. Stick to the guidelines and plan everything out beforehand and you should be fine.
